Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation2: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was helping Mr. Carter, who was still groggy from his surgery, sit up in bed. I glanced at the screen and saw a message from Jamie: “Ugh, today’s been endless. Can you talk?” I knew she needed me to listen, to be the friend who always made time, who never brushed her off. But Mr. Carter was struggling, his hand trembling as he tried to pull on his hospital gown. I could see the frustration in his eyes, and I knew he was counting on me to be patient, gentle, and attentive. My mind raced—if I replied to Jamie, I’d be distracted from my patient, but if I ignored her, I’d be letting her down when she needed support. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt torn, standing there with my phone in one hand and Mr. Carter’s sleeve in the other, caught between being the friend Jamie needed and the nursing assistant Mr. Carter depended on.
